title: Mars - Frontier
features: Sometimes it takes a catastrophe for science to leap forward.

On May 20th, 2069, the space vessel “Phoenix” embarks on its journey to Mars – humankind’s next frontier. Led by Commander Joy Liore, the 7 international crewmates’ goal is to explore possible colonization on the Red Planet’s surface.They confirm landing.Then they vanish.Five days after all contact with Phoenix is lost, Doctor M. Tzuk, an expert interplanetary psychologist, accepts NASA’s appointment as head of the investigation force.The investigation will take her from the safety of the Houston Space Center to the desolate surface of Mars, where she will discover more about the human spirit than she ever thought possible.The Red Planet changes people. And as with those who came before her, Dr. Tzuk must walk the balance between the hopes and dreams of mankind – and her own.
“In space there are no tracks to follow. Success and failure are measured in the very act of landing. Anything after that, however, is any man’s game.”
description: My first aspiration was to become a nun. I was five. A strange career goal for a Jewish kid. However, Isaac Asimov's books changed my outlook: A space psychologist sounded much better than a nun. I am a Psychologist, but I reach the stars only in my fantasies. So, let's embark on the Phoenix - with Joy, CU62 and others, and enjoy an incredible voyage into the future - toward Mars. Dr. M. Tzuk will tell our story. But when we land we will remember that in all of us travelers, the human spirit is revealed in its finest, even as disaster brings us crashing into the cliffs of the universe.

author: {'avatar': 'https://m.media-amazon.com/images/S/amzn-author-media-prod/ts0mbrfi359s1gfeobu9kua4qk._SY600_.jpg', 'name': 'Henya Shanun-Klein', 'about': ['Dr. Henya Shanun-Klein is a Professor of Psychology (PhD) and a Thanatologist (FT) in the United States. She is the founder of the Thanatology Program in Israel, a lecturer, researcher, published author, therapist, and a long-time volunteer for international rescue organizations. Shanun-Klein is a pioneer in her studies on Parental Bereavement, and has served on the ADEC committee helping to compose the Code of Ethics. Born in Europe as the second generation of Holocaust survivors, she grew up in Israel and served in the Israeli army.', 'Henya is the widow of Professor Norman Kagan, and a bereaved mother of her beloved daughter Gili Klein. Her cherished son Shai and granddaughters Jessica and Mika are a source of great comfort, joy and happiness to her.']}
